I got 1 week into the new year feeling great and here we are, like clockwork, it's worn off.

I'm sad and angry and frustrated and overwhelmed. I feel like shit. I was exercising every day, been eating fruit and veg every single day, I don't get what's gone wrong...

Fuck it, I'm just gonna rant... But I wish I had somebody to listen to me and be there for me. None of my friends are responding to my messages. Feel like I may as well have been wiped off the face of the earth. ONE person keeps in contact with me, and that's my ex, which isn't as bad as it sounds, we've got a healthy friendship because the romance just wasn't there but we enjoyed each others company, so that's fine. But man... I feel bad messaging them all the time... It's cause nobody else will reply to me.

I'm trying to cull all my shit. Trying to get rid of all the things I've accumulated. I think I have a compulsive shopping disorder or something, but I don't even like having this much stuff! It's been good getting rid of things but every now and then I hit a wall. It becomes too much for me to face. It's overwhelming and exhausting. I wish I had somebody to help me, but it's just me keeping myself accountable, keeping myself going...

Having to stay strong... is so hard... I wish I had the mental fortitude to get up every day and do my best, and really work towards making my life, my environment, better. I want to be happy. I want to live easily.... I just want things to be simple. Fuck. I want to be skinny, I want to own nothing but things I LOVE. I want to have my own house... I want to have my own kitchen. I want to have my friends over. I want to be able to live a normal, healthy, happy life. I feel like I've been forgotten.

And you know what's fucked? all of these awful feelings have come back to me since my mom came back home. She was away for holidays and I had the place to myself. Just bliss. Freedom. It was great. And now she's back home and I already feel like a servant on call.

posts.sub: How do I deradicalize myself from racist views?
posts.com:
I used to have a civic nationalist mindset regarding race, and I used to regard racism as antisocial behavior. I started browsing /pol/ and similar places during the lockdowns and the summer 2020 riots, getting into race realism and whatnot. For 6 months, I watched Blacks torch the entire country, and people (including public officials) seemed to cheer it on as if it were totally normal. So at the time, it seemed like the alt-right people were a far more sane community than the anti-racists/non-racists.

Fast forward to now, I have trouble not seeing race. My tendencies have caused me to instantly judge people based on race, before getting to know them. It has caused problems with my interpersonal relationships. I feel very bitter and angry towards the world all the time. I even sympathize with terrorists and mass shooters sometimes, especially when they have a racist ideology (most do).

I hate being like this, and I just want to be normal and at peace. Anyone have any good tips for deradicalization from the alt-right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
not to sound cliche, but you need to spend less time online and go touch some grass. i had this problem in the opposite direction- i was a far-left extremist and felt similar problems with anger and difficulty socializing.

you need to get back out into the real world, out of the online echo chambers. join a local club, doesn't matter what it's for. hiking, dancing, martial arts, pottery, whatever you can stand long enough to do it in a room with ten or so other people.

talk to them about anything other than politics. you're detoxing from extremism, essentially, just shoot the shit about whatever. if someone else brings up politics, try and change the subject. it's gonna suck for a while. you'll probably hate it at first. but keep going, keep talking to them, and eventually you'll find these things matter less and less the more time you spend out in the real world, with regular people who don't care about this stuff.

while you're doing this, if you have the money, cognitive behavioral therapy from a licensed therapist will also help you detox from these thoughts and find your peace.

posts.sub: Tips on reconnecting with an old friend?
posts.com:
I'm talking about my ex-wife's little brother. He's 16-17 now, we divorced with his big sister around 2 years ago and I lost contact with him shortly after. We dated and were married with his sister for a loooong time, so I pretty much was always in his life since he can remember. I have little brothers the same age, and that kid just became like an extra brother to me. He didn't have any brothers of his own, I feel like me being a big brother to him was a big thing for him. His mom used to tell me that often.

We used to all kinds of stuff together, same as I did with my own brothers. Sports, helping with homework, just talking and watching youtube, whatever.

After the divorce I tried to keep doing stuff with him occasionally and it was fine for a while, we went out to play basketball like normal and stuff. But at some point pretty soon, our lives just got distant, and I didn't want to keep pushing it. I was afraid I might seem overly pushy for asking him to do stuff randomly all the time. And in the back of my head I didn't want to stay that close to my ex-wife anymore. I just didn't ask him to do stuff anymore, I decided that if he wanted to do stuff and asked me, I'd say yes immediately, but I wouldn't ask him. It got quiet pretty fast and we haven't seen after that. Some months later he called me for a couple of seconds. I asked him what that was about, and he said just an accident. I think it was him deleting my number on his phone...

How do you try to reconnect at this point? I'd love to know what he's up to and what kind of guy he's growing up to be. From what I hear, he's sounding a lot like me at his age. Getting into the same music and apparently learning guitar and drums like me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28067177
Part of why I'm so hesitant to just message him is because I don't know how he feels about me currently. His sister is the type to talk shit about people so she might have told him that I'm a bigger piece of shit than I actually am. I don't think he would believe that talk, but who knows.

I'm watching my brothers of the same age growing up, and I can see how big of a help them having an older brother is at this point in their lives when they start to move out and live their own life, or finishing high school and planning their next move. I keep thinking about my ex's bro and how he doesn't have that support. I really would just like to go play ball with him and hit a burger place again, and just talk all that shit out.

Thanks for reading my blog.

Just recently had it as well.
Get "Antiscabiosum" from the local pharmacy. Apply it for three days straight, every inch! of the body. If you itch over your head, apply to the head too. The lotion does not smell pleasant, I got headaches from it too, but it worked. I just went to a student counsellor (free that way) and she gave me realistic goals and I achieved them and before I knew it I was structured all on my own.
>Start small, say, wake up before 9 every morning.
>Do that for a week to a month consistently.
>Add another small thing, like having a bath before you go to bed.
>Do that consistently until you're comfortable.
>Add something else, maybe you read during your bath.
>Do consistently for a week, two weeks, whatever.

The harder stuff is going to the gym, but if you find a good one with a pool and a sauna you can go there first, then once you're consistently going you can add the gym and have the sauna as a reward.

That's, more or less, what works for me. Basically tricking myself into doing difficult things, and also just accumulating positive habits. It helps if you keep a vice to reward yourself with too, at least that has helped me. I get shit done during the day and get high in the evenings as a reward.

>>28065624
My general advice is see a physical therapist, this stuff is easy for them to take care of but is more complicated than a lot of runners think.

Where exactly is the pain? The front of your shin or the back/inner aspect? Pain at the back is mostly due to weak calves which causes your shin bone to take on too much force. Pain at the front is a bit rarer but mostly comes down to shitty running technique.

Please please understand that shin splints is mostly load-related and won't get better unless you take time off. Take a week off at least, and return to running at 50% the weekly distance you do know. In the meantime, work on having a higher cadence and having very strongs calves; you should be able to do about 22 single leg calf raises on each side.

>t. Physiotherapist and runner

>>28065776
I am so sorry you're going through this. This will be the hardest challenge of your life. Without knowing your circumstances, I PROMISE you that you will be able to get through this, and life will still have meaning after. But it's going to be very painful and it might take years to work through this.
Is hospice care an option for her? They might be better equipped than you are to help her be comfortable. You've done so much already, you've cared for her as best as you can. You deserve support and help and relief. It might be a better option for both of you.
I am sorry to say this. You're going to loose her soon. She'll be gone. The love she had for you her entire life won't be gone. The good she did, the memories, the hope - that is going to keep living with you. Through your actions and your memories and who you are. But her life on earth will be over soon. And you'll have to come to terms with that, as hard as it is.
I would encourage you to see if your work, your church, the hospital, (or any other community you have) have resources for this situation. Many places offer free counseling, estate planning, chaplain services. You need help. This is too much for you to fight alone. And that doesn't mean anything is wrong with you. This would hurt anyone, no matter how strong.
Wishing you and your family the very best. This is going to hurt very badly, and for a long time. You might not believe this now, but this won't destroy your life. You can still be happy, find fulfillment, and overcome this. It will take a long, long time. But never give up. Never, never, never give up. Her love for you, and your love for her, are NOT dying now. The end of a life is not the end of love.
Condolences.

I do not feel like an adult whatsoever, I feel I have not changed from the child I was when my neuroses started.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Can a community replace family? Families provide support and companionship through good and bad times but is this not also the function of any strong, caring community like a church, sport club or activity group?

I've read arguments that the desire for family itself is secondary to the more basic human need which is one of *community.* Family is simply the quickest way to create your own community, both by creating new connections (i.e having kids) and linking pre-existing ones (the merging of two families).

The flip side of this is that anybody who already sits within a healthy, supportive community isn't necessarily gaining anything by starting a family. Note that this is entirely separate from marriage; there is and always will be a basic need for intimacy in most people.

Given the currently awful economics of starting a family, this may be useful. Furthermore, caring, well-knit communities are genuinely rare these days, thus misleading more people into thinking they cannot get a communal sense of companionship without a family.

Thoughts? Rebuttals? I'm not dissing family, I just think the argument is interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28066436
Family is the highest form of community, so much so that the highest compliment you can give another community is to say "we're like family". So yes, but it's very hard to replicate the intimacy of a truly loving family.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28066452
That's a pretty good point. Again, I only feel that the argument only matters in very few contexts. e.g: people who cannot financially or biologically have children.

I agree but there are two flaws in that strat:

a) It requires others to share your opinion of family. YOU might consider your community family but they may not reciprocate that; this becomes an issue if you require their support during especially hard times.

b) People can be genuinely selfish. You could argue that part of why families *can* be so supportive is that they are ultimately coerced to do by social expectation and the fact they live together (i.e, they cannot escape each other's problems).

Accept it is usually the most straight forward thing to do.

I used to lurk so much on R9k, fa and such preaching the "it's over... Blah blah" scpheel. But then I went to the 'just shave it route" and it helped a bit.
But then I'd be at the gym looking at all the other guys and their thinning hair and think to myself
>"Oh no mate, he needs to shave his hair" "ahhh what's he doing? His hairs thinning but he keeps it long, why"
On the inside I was still projecting onto others because I still wasn't comfortable in myself. It wasn't until I was about to walk into the gym one day when I saw a man walking down the street. Absolutely handsome chad face, suit and tie with a brief case. With completely bald receded head on top with long hair at the sides. And I thought "if a man like that can proudly walk the streets looking that damn impressive. Then why the fuck do I care about this so much"
And slowly I began to truly except myself and become comfortable in my own skin. It wasn't sudden, but gradual. And I realised in the massive grand scheme of life it doesn't really matter.

It's a lot to it without going into a full 50 minute ted talk. But just accepting it and living your life instead of ruminating is the first step forward.

posts.name: Anonymous

The fan is vibrating at the higher speed slowly working the screws loose and sometimes causing the clicking as it shakes. Finding a sweet spot on the set screws can help, but trying a rubber washer or appropriately sized metal washer can help reduce the vibration.

Yes, it mostly does, I am well aware. But some amount of leakage is inevitable, and we suspect that this leakage amounts to far more damage than is currently supposed by most scientists. Additionally, such notions are based on perfect injection procedure. If mistakes are made, as is likely to happen when you administer some 13 billion COVID shots, then the leakage is far worse.
Lastly, these studies aren't actually as definitive as you think. We've actually be surprised to find just how much the lipid nanoparticle prefers to go to the liver, for example. Remember that the mRNA can last for days and the spike protein lasts for weeks.
Additionally, what you and every other moron on the planet is forgetting here is that the spike protein itself is a homing vector. That is, it is the portion of the virus used to interface with its host and it has preferences for particular receptors on particular cells. Because of this, it causes leaked protein to target particular regions of the body. This means that the vast majority of the spike protein that does leak ends up reaching places like the heart, the kidneys, and so on. The issue is that the spike protein is damaging these organs by effectively the same mechanism as the virus itself, so the damage blends together when studied in aggregate.
I am willing to believe that I am wrong or that my ideas could be refined, but it is no longer a debate that the vaccine can induce heart disease and does so at a more frequent rate than previous vaccines. Have been trying to "strengthen" my mind through stoicism,and all the other bs, but I'm still as emotional and "weak" as ever. I'm not trying to be a victim here. I genuinely want to be a better human. But what's actually going to stick? There's no point in trying things again and again with no results.

You try, you fail, you try, you fail, but the only true failure is when you stop trying.

You need to understand willpower and wisdom doesn't come to those who just read and study all day. It's learning and taking action immediately. I know you're struggling, I know it feels impossible. No One can help you, you and ONLY you know what needs to be done. Don't lie to yourself, do what needs to be done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28065615
The point is to keep trying, teach yourself ways to fight the darkness when it arises, and never give up no matter what. It will be very difficult if your brain is addicted to negative emotions/chemicals, it has to be actively trained to become accustomed to positive emotions/chemicals.

A fact of human existence is that shitty things will keep happening, you have to trick your mind into not letting them get you down. You will never reach a finish line, you win by not letting it get to you and finding ways to live in the moment and appreciate every single day.

People with mental illnesses frequently seem to think that the solution is to find someone who is similarly ill and therein find an understanding, compassionate partner. It is true that you will be able to trauma bond quite well and you will be able to feel open, but you will also have to deal with a mutually ill relationship that sees instability from both sides. A single BPD person is usually enough to tank a relationship, so imagine two of them together. I made a similar mistake in that I pursued women who were depressed. In your mind, you imagine two depressed people who understand each other and help each other out of it. In practice, an episode of depression in one person triggers it in the other and creates a positive feedback loop.

posts.com:
Doctors throw out the BPD diagnosis like candy now OP. I'm pretty sure they are just getting kick backs for pushing anti depressants and mood stabilizers.

I went to a doctor because I went psychotic for a week and couldn't sleep, had some kind of strange physical break down, was pretty sure I had some kind of infection or poison reaction to something that triggered it all. Doctor tells me to go see a mental health specialist, so I go, and after talking for maybe 2 minutes they tell me I'm bi polar and to take lithium. I say no, go to a therapist, therapist says they agree, and I say no and that I would rather try therapy for a bit. Spend a few months going over my upbringing of being exposed to violence, all types of abuse, crime, etc, talk about my marriage ending a couple years prior, the world being a clown fest for the past two years, just general stress. The therapist then tells me she thinks I actually have various ptsd and maybe after a couple years of stress it finally released after decades of holding things in. Felt nice to get things out. Never went back after that.

Go talk to a therapist or medical professional for more than a session if you haven't. Doctors are pill dispensers and will fuck your chemistry up if you let them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>What are the chances that my past actions online will come back to haunt me?
It's 0% if you don't let it.

The way you heal from trauma is that you have to get immediate closure as soon as possible; and as you grow, things are inclined to be action oriented than by situation.

***

To expound mathematically(I apologize for the mathematical gibberish, you can fast forward to the conclusion):
What do you think is the value of a day for a three year old compared to a day for a 45 year old looks like?

a. 1 day for a three year old is (1÷365)÷3 = 0.000913242009132 or around 0.09%

b. 1 day for a 45 year old is (1÷365)÷45 = 0.000060882800609 or only 0.006%

***

Now the above check for a few things:
1. Now if you take both their values and appropriate, a day for three year old is 14.999999999950726 or 15 times more valuable than a day for a 45 year old. Following this, whatever happens on the young person's day increases in magnitude dramatically in comparison to someone who is older: happiness, fear, sadness, hate, bravery, etc.

2. A day can be two days, a week, a month(prolonged events such as a sprain, breaking a leg, depression) - this will alter the calculation significantly which is why closure has to be attained properly. The longer you are held by something, the more valuable it becomes(this applies to happiness as well).

3. This is also the math to "Time heals all things(almost)", the older you get the more insignificant an event will grow. The best thing you can do about something bad that happened is proper closure and simply live a long life.

The main issue with these dead bedroom scenarios is that they are symptomatic, not causative. That is, the dead bedroom implies an unexpected and significant drop in sex from the norm. This never comes from nothing; there must be a cause to it.
However, it's like diagnosing your illness on WedMD. You have a sneeze? Well, it could be a cold, or it could be nasal cancer. There are a lot of possible causes for it.
1) Physical inadequacy/hygiene issues (not applicable to you)
2) Major relationship issues, like fidelity causing one partner to lose sexual interest
3) Issues restarting after a deliberate pause
4) Mental or physical issues with the LL partner
5) the LL could be hiding something, like an affair or an unexpected sexual orientation
6) issues communicating and expressing how they want to fuck
I am sure you are doing more things wrong than you say, but I can identify some "wrong" things in just this post.
>'play' aspect, 'sexy naughty playful' vibe
It may be that this just isn't the vibe she wants. It may not feel like you are pressuring her, but pressuring someone to be vanilla is still pressure. She may prefer a submissive, obedient position during sex, for example - diligent and serious in pleasuring her man. It may be that she prefers to dom and feels like she can't express that.
It may also be that this is the vibe she wants and there is another issue at play, but it stuck out to me as a potential mistake.
>she's generous in that she buys me stuff, cooks me food, does a lot of the housework etc.
It won't hurt to try and do more around the house if you can. It will directly reduce her stress and improve her libido (albeit perhaps not much) and it shows you care about her (they call it "acts of service", it's one of the love languages).
